description: The Second Floor presents early Italian painting through the High Renaissance, featuring masterpieces from Giotto to Michelangelo.

items.title: Introduction
items.description: An overview of the Uffizi's second-floor route, introducing the main historical periods and the layout of the galleries.

items.title: Lorraine Vestibule
items.description: Entrance vestibule area that leads into the early painting galleries on the second floor.

items.title: Eastern Corridor
items.description: Long corridor that forms part of the main second-floor circuit, connecting multiple rooms and sections.

items.title: 13th Century Paintings
items.description: A starting point for the collection's earliest panel paintings, introducing medieval Italian painting and its devotional formats.

items.title: 'Primitivi' Rooms
items.description: Galleries dedicated to early Italian painting, often focusing on landmark artists who shaped late medieval art.

items.title: Ognissanti Madonna
items.description: A large altarpiece Madonna and Child enthroned, with saints and angels, representing a major step toward naturalism in early Italian painting. Giotto's revolutionary approach to space and volume marked a decisive break from Byzantine traditions.

image.alt: Giotto, Ognissanti Madonna

viewing_tips: Notice how Giotto creates a sense of three-dimensional space
Compare with the Byzantine-style Madonnas in the same room
Look at the realistic expressions on the angels' faces

items.title: Sienese School of Painting, 14th Century
items.description: A section devoted to 14th-century Sienese painting, known for elegance, refined line, and luminous color.

items.title: Annunciation
items.description: A celebrated Gothic masterpiece depicting the Angel Gabriel announcing to the Virgin Mary, renowned for its refined style and brilliant decorative detail. The gold background and sinuous lines exemplify the elegance of Sienese painting.

image.alt: Simone Martini and Lippo Memmi, Annunciation

viewing_tips: Admire the intricate gold toolwork in the background
Notice the Virgin's startled gesture
Look for the olive branch the angel carries

items.title: Presentation at the Temple
items.description: A narrative religious scene showing the Presentation, reflecting 14th-century innovations in storytelling and spatial organization. Lorenzetti's architectural setting creates an unprecedented sense of depth.

image.alt: Ambrogio Lorenzetti, Presentation at the Temple

viewing_tips: Study the architectural perspective
Notice how figures interact within the space

items.title: The 14th Century in Florence
items.description: A section exploring Florentine painting of the 1300s, bridging medieval tradition and early Renaissance developments.

items.title: Masterpieces of International Gothic
items.description: Works connected to the International Gothic style, characterized by elegance, rich surface detail, and courtly refinement.

items.title: The Coronation of the Virgin
items.description: A large, richly colored altarpiece celebrating the Coronation of the Virgin, a key subject in late medieval devotional art. The flowing draperies and luminous colors showcase the International Gothic style at its height.

image.alt: Lorenzo Monaco, The Coronation of the Virgin

viewing_tips: Notice the rich ultramarine blue used throughout
Look at the elaborate textile patterns

items.title: Adoration of the Magi
items.description: A famous International Gothic altarpiece depicting the Magi's visit, celebrated for its intricate detail, lavish materials, and storytelling richness. The procession winds through the landscape in a continuous narrative.

image.alt: Gentile da Fabriano, Adoration of the Magi

viewing_tips: Follow the procession from the distant hills to the foreground
Look for the exotic animals in the retinue
Notice the gold leaf details on the harnesses and crowns

items.title: Early Renaissance
items.description: A section focused on the early 1400s, when artists transformed painting through perspective, anatomy, and more lifelike space.

items.title: Madonna and Child with Saint Anne
items.description: A Madonna and Child with Saint Anne demonstrating Masaccio's pioneering early Renaissance approach, emphasizing volume, light, and human presence. The collaboration between Masaccio and Masolino shows two different artistic approaches.

image.alt: Masaccio and Masolino, Madonna and Child with Saint Anne

viewing_tips: Compare the sculptural Virgin by Masaccio with the more delicate Saint Anne by Masolino
Notice how light creates solid forms

items.title: Battle of San Romano
items.description: A dramatic battle scene known for its structured composition and striking use of perspective in a complex narrative setting. Uccello's obsession with mathematical perspective creates an almost surreal battlefield.

image.alt: Paolo Uccello, Battle of San Romano

viewing_tips: Notice how the fallen lances create perspective lines
Look for the geometric patterns in the composition
This is one of three panels - the others are in London and Paris

items.title: Duke and Duchess of Urbino
items.description: A celebrated double portrait showing the rulers of Urbino in profile, admired for its clarity, calm geometry, and landscape setting. The diptych format with continuous landscape background was revolutionary.

image.alt: Piero della Francesca, Duke and Duchess of Urbino

viewing_tips: Look at the continuous landscape across both panels
The Duke's profile hides his right side - damaged in a tournament
Notice the allegorical scenes on the reverse side

items.title: Madonna and Child with Two Angels
items.description: A tender Madonna and Child image by Filippo Lippi, known as the 'Lippina'. Associated with the grace and warmth of Florentine 15th-century painting, it influenced generations of artists including Botticelli.

image.alt: Filippo Lippi, Madonna and Child with Two Angels

viewing_tips: Notice the playful angel looking directly at the viewer
The landscape through the window shows Lippi's interest in nature
This work greatly influenced Botticelli, Lippi's student

items.title: The Pollaiolos
items.description: A section centered on the Pollaiuolo brothers, known for dynamic figures, anatomy studies, and energetic Renaissance compositions.

items.title: Botticelli Rooms
items.description: The Uffizi's most famous galleries for Botticelli, housing iconic mythological paintings alongside key religious works.

items.title: Primavera (Spring)
items.description: A large mythological allegory set in a garden, featuring a procession of figures often associated with themes of love, renewal, and harmony. The painting's meaning has been debated for centuries, with interpretations ranging from Neoplatonic philosophy to Medici wedding celebrations.

image.alt: Sandro Botticelli, Primavera (Spring)

viewing_tips: Identify the figures: Zephyr, Chloris, Flora, Venus, the Three Graces, Mercury
Notice the hundreds of plant species depicted
Look for the orange grove setting associated with the Medici

items.title: The Birth of Venus
items.description: Venus arrives by sea on a shell in one of the most iconic images of the Italian Renaissance, celebrated for its poetic style and linear elegance. The goddess emerges fully grown from the sea foam, blown to shore by the winds.

image.alt: Sandro Botticelli, The Birth of Venus

viewing_tips: Notice the wind gods Zephyr and Aura on the left
The Hour on the right offers a cloak decorated with flowers
The pose echoes ancient Venus Pudica sculptures

items.title: Madonna del Magnificat
items.description: A round (tondo) painting of the Madonna and Child, surrounded by angels, known for its delicate beauty and refined composition. The Virgin is shown writing the Magnificat prayer while crowned by angels.

image.alt: Sandro Botticelli, Madonna del Magnificat

viewing_tips: Notice the curved perspective adapted to the round format
The Virgin writes 'Magnificat anima mea Dominum'
Angels hold an inkwell and book for her

items.title: Portinari Triptych
items.description: A monumental Northern Renaissance triptych that had major impact in Florence, admired for realism, detail, and intense devotional presence. Commissioned by Tommaso Portinari, the Medici bank agent in Bruges.

image.alt: Hugo van der Goes, Portinari Triptych

viewing_tips: Notice the realistic shepherds compared to idealized Italian figures
Study the still-life details: flowers with symbolic meanings
Compare Northern and Italian approaches to naturalism

items.title: Terrace to the Map Room
items.description: A transitional terrace area leading toward the Map Room, connecting visitors along the second-floor circuit.

items.title: Stanzino delle Matematiche
items.description: A specialized room historically linked to scientific instruments and learning themes within the Uffizi's broader Medici context.

items.title: Buontalenti's Tribune
items.description: A historic octagonal room created for displaying prized Medici treasures, famous for its rich decoration and central role in the gallery's history.

items.title: Ancient Armoury
items.description: In the current official map, this area corresponds to the sequence dedicated to the Renaissance beyond the Alps (A17-A20).

items.title: Adoration of the Magi
items.description: A Northern Renaissance depiction of the Magi's visit by Durer, known for precision, detail, and a distinct approach to form and landscape. The work shows Durer's mastery after his Italian journeys.

image.alt: Albrecht Durer, Adoration of the Magi

viewing_tips: Notice the Northern European attention to texture and detail
Compare with Italian treatments of the same subject
Look for Durer's characteristic precision in the drapery

items.title: Cabinet of Miniatures
items.description: A gallery devoted to small-scale works and miniatures, highlighting refined craftsmanship in compact formats.

items.title: Corridoio di Mezzogiorno
items.description: One of the Uffizi's major corridors, part of the architectural spine that links rooms and showcases elements of the collection.

items.title: Corridoio di Ponente
items.description: West corridor area along the second-floor route, connecting key Renaissance rooms and major display spaces.

items.title: Laocoon
items.description: A powerful sculptural group based on the ancient Laocoon theme, associated with dramatic movement and intense expression.

image.alt: Baccio Bandinelli, Laocoon

viewing_tips: Compare with the famous Roman original in the Vatican

items.title: Second Renaissance
items.description: A section focused on mature 15th-century developments, linking Florentine innovation with broader Italian Renaissance currents.

items.title: Altarpiece of Santa Lucia dei Magnoli
items.description: A landmark Florentine altarpiece admired for its clear light, balanced composition, and refined color harmonies. The sacra conversazione format shows saints gathered around the Virgin in an architectural setting.

image.alt: Domenico Veneziano, Altarpiece of Santa Lucia dei Magnoli

viewing_tips: Notice the soft, diffused light - Domenico's specialty
The architectural setting creates depth through perspective

items.title: Adoration of the Magi
items.description: A richly populated Adoration scene that reflects late 15th-century narrative complexity and expressive character detail. Filippino was the son of Fra Filippo Lippi and continued his father's legacy.

image.alt: Filippino Lippi, Adoration of the Magi

viewing_tips: Look for the many portrait figures in the crowd
Notice the archaeological details from ancient Rome

items.title: Perseus Freeing Andromeda
items.description: A mythological scene of rescue and drama, notable for imaginative storytelling and an unusual, dreamlike visual world. Piero di Cosimo was known for his eccentric personality and fantastical subjects.

image.alt: Piero di Cosimo, Perseus Freeing Andromeda

viewing_tips: Notice the bizarre sea monster
Look for the celebratory crowd after the rescue

items.title: Holy Family
items.description: A Holy Family composition associated with Signorelli's interest in anatomy, strong forms, and expressive figure design. His muscular style influenced Michelangelo.

image.alt: Luca Signorelli, Holy Family

viewing_tips: Notice Signorelli's emphasis on muscular anatomy
The tondo format was popular for domestic devotion

items.title: Leonardo Room
items.description: A dedicated gallery centered on Leonardo da Vinci's works and related paintings from the late 15th century.

items.title: Annunciation
items.description: A refined Annunciation scene with careful perspective, detailed natural observation, and a luminous landscape depth typical of Leonardo's early style. Painted while Leonardo was still in Verrocchio's workshop.

image.alt: Leonardo da Vinci, Annunciation

viewing_tips: Notice Leonardo's sfumato technique in the distant landscape
Study the botanical accuracy of the flowers
The marble lectern shows perspective slightly adjusted for a side view

items.title: Adoration of the Magi
items.description: An unfinished but influential composition showing the Magi's visit, revealing Leonardo's dynamic planning, complex grouping, and expressive drawing. The work was left incomplete when Leonardo departed for Milan.

image.alt: Leonardo da Vinci, Adoration of the Magi

viewing_tips: The unfinished state reveals Leonardo's working process
Notice the swirling composition centered on the Virgin
Background scenes include horsemen and architectural ruins

items.title: The Baptism of Christ
items.artist: Andrea del Verrocchio and Leonardo da Vinci
items.description: A collaborative workshop painting depicting Christ's baptism, traditionally linked to Verrocchio's studio with contributions attributed to Leonardo. The young Leonardo reportedly painted the left angel.

image.alt: Verrocchio and Leonardo, The Baptism of Christ

viewing_tips: Compare the left angel (Leonardo) with the right (Verrocchio)
Notice Leonardo's sfumato in the distant landscape
The story says Verrocchio gave up painting after seeing Leonardo's work

items.title: Ricetto delle Iscrizioni Antiche
items.description: A transitional space associated with inscriptions and antiquities, connecting rooms in the second-floor sequence.

items.title: Raphael and Michelangelo
items.description: A key section presenting works by Raphael and Michelangelo, among the most important highlights of the Uffizi's Renaissance holdings.

items.title: Doni Tondo (Holy Family)
items.description: Michelangelo's famous circular Holy Family, celebrated for its sculptural power, bold color, and complex figure movement. The only completed panel painting by Michelangelo, it shows his characteristic interest in the human form.

image.alt: Michelangelo, Doni Tondo

viewing_tips: Notice how figures twist like sculptures
The nudes in the background are mysterious - perhaps pagan souls before Christ
The original frame was also designed by Michelangelo

items.title: Madonna del Cardellino (Madonna of the Goldfinch)
items.description: A Madonna and Child with the infant St. John, admired for Raphael's balanced composition, tenderness, and harmonious color. The goldfinch symbolizes Christ's future Passion.

image.alt: Raphael, Madonna del Cardellino

viewing_tips: The pyramidal composition creates perfect balance
Notice Raphael's soft sfumato learned from Leonardo
The painting was shattered in 1547 and later restored

items.title: Portraits of Agnolo and Maddalena Doni
items.description: A pair of Renaissance portraits known for calm presence, refined drawing, and a carefully constructed sense of character and status. Painted for the same patrons who commissioned Michelangelo's Doni Tondo.

image.alt: Raphael, Portraits of Agnolo and Maddalena Doni

viewing_tips: Compare with Leonardo's Mona Lisa - note the similar pose for Maddalena
The landscape background shows Raphael's debt to Flemish painting
Rich jewelry displays the couple's wealth

items.title: The Niobe Room
items.description: A monumental room associated with classical sculpture and one of the Uffizi's most architecturally striking gallery spaces.

items.title: Madonna of the Harpies
items.description: A major altarpiece showing the Madonna enthroned with saints, notable for its clarity, harmony, and refined High Renaissance style. The 'harpies' are actually sphinxes on the pedestal.

image.alt: Andrea del Sarto, Madonna of the Harpies

viewing_tips: Look at the sphinxes on the pedestal (not harpies)
Notice the perfect balance of the composition
Del Sarto was called 'the faultless painter'
